A funny thing happened on the way to the movie theater tonight. The third installment of the Scary Movie series is not only PG-13, but is directed by comedy legend/genius David Zucker. Although he took over a series from the Wayans Brothers, Zucker turned it around into something almost completely new. It isn't quite in the same vein as his one true classic, Airplane!, but it shows how he should stay away from movies like My Boss's Daughter and go back into the spoof genre which got him, and his team, off the ground.The first movie based its main parodies around Scream and I Know What You Did Last Summer, and the second was mainly revolved around The Haunting. Scary Movie 3 has two central spoofs: The Ring and Signs. The protagonist from the first two, Cindy (Anna Faris), is now an anchorwoman who investigates a mysterious videotape while odd crop circles appear. Many celebrities have cameos in parodies of recent movies.Instead of extremely crude sexual humor, Zucker knew that you don't need lewdness to make people laugh. One of the reasons why Airplane! was so great is because it was only rated PG; almost all of the humor was situational and not just shock value. Sure, Scary Movie 3 had its share of crude humor, but it wasn't as over-the-top and unnecessary as the other two's were. Instead, what he did was take his parodies and make them seem possible. For example, George Carlin plays The Architect (a parody of The Matrix Reloaded) who spends all of his time alone in a giant room. He gets so lonely, he `bonds' with his chair, what most people would do.Also, what made Scary Movie 3 funny is how it pointed out the faults of the movies that it is spoofing. Throughout Signs, Mel Gibson doesn't even mention farming once, although he lives out on a farm. Charlie Sheen, who mocks the Gibson character, continuously talks about it for the first few minutes he's on screen. In 8 Mile, one of the things I hated about it was how everyone was speaking with huge words; here, parodies of those characters do exactly this.Scary Movie 3 did have some gags that didn't work, especially around the middle of the film. It seems that Zucker just wanted to move as quickly as possible and instead of making it even 90 minutes (it's about 75) he just wanted to make a quick, short parody film. Although Carlin's character was okay, Eddie Griffin and Queen Latifah's characters (as characters from The Matrix) weren't utilized as much as they should have been. Also, Leslie Nielsen, who has been in most of the Zucker spoofs, has a small role as the President and plays a typical Nielsen character. I would have liked to have seen more of him, but at least he was able to deliver a classic Airplane! line.Scary Movie 3 is one of the funniest movies of the year, with its almost continuous laughter. It's probably the best one out of the three in the series.My rating: 7/10Rated PG-13 for pervasive crude and sexual humor, language, comic violence and drug references.

In the third installment of the Scary Movie-series the directors-chair is turned over to comedy-veteran David Zucker. Something that feels sensible considering how lousy the second movie truly was.Here the target of the spoofs are mostly Shyamalans "Signs" and the American version of "The Ring", but also other movies like "The Matrix" get their share. What becomes apparent right from the start is how much better the comedy works here than in Scary Movie 2. It's still no amazing comedy or masterpiece. But it's not a complete failure like the second movie. It seems David Zucker has a stronger feeling for what works on screen. Also the actors help. Charlie Sheen still has that special comic timing that made the Hot Shots-movies so good, and Simon Rex is pretty funny too. Especially in his "8 Mile"-scenes.In short you should probably not watch this is if you feel that serious cinema or pretentious comedy is your calling. But if you enjoyed movies like "The Naked Gun", "Hot Shots" and other similar outings it's quite possible that you will find this at least decent entertainment. I rate it 5/10.

The third installment of the "Scary Movie" franchise comes to us directed by David Zucker, one of the men behind "Airplane!", the original spoof movie. Even without the Wayans Brothers behind it, "Scary Movie 3" often hits its mark.  The parodies of such recent horror movies and thrillers like "The Ring" and "Signs" are successful.  There are some signs the franchise may be on the decline, by casting actors like Leslie Nielsen of "Airplane!" and Charlie Sheen of "Hot Shots!", who seem to have a new niche in spoofs.  But I'd say "Scary Movie 3" is a hilarious companion to its two forerunners.

I rather enjoyed this low-brow comedy, and its mishmash parody of various horror movies (including "The Ring", "Signs" and "8 Mile") and other aspects of Hollywood culture. It was all rather cliché and slapstick, but at the same time it was well done, fast paced, irreverent, sort of fun, and quite unpredictable. Appearing in the film are a number of good comedians and off-the-wall personalities. I enjoyed Scary Movie 1, way back when, and it was interesting to catch up with the series. This movie didn't blow me away, but it was entertaining enough. I'm tempted to give it about a 7, but I think it merits a 6 because of its general crudity and overt stupidity.

Second scary movie was a little bit of underwhelming disaster) but this one, for me, strongly put the franchise back on track!!!Absolutely loved it, for any movie buff and horror fan, it is definitely an ultimate fun watch!

Scary Movie 3 follows on from the disastrous Scary Movie 2, this time spoofing mainly The Ring and Signs. It involves a random plot to do with aliens coming to earth and the cursed videotape from The Ring with some random Matrix and 8 Mile related stuff thrown in. This one improves considerably on the second, and is to be honest my favourite of the series so far. It's certainly not great. Leslie Nielsen, though he's excellent as always, isn't in it enough while the jokes are somewhat hit and miss. In fairness, quite a few of them do (There's a certain scene in the middle which I don't want to spoil since it's that good which had me in utter hysterics) but others are too obvious, overstretched, inept or occasionally just a bit offensive. The movie is a mess (How did this cost $48 million?!) but perhaps that adds to its silly charm. It's pretty funny much of the time, even if it isn't particularly good in terms of plot or intelligence. However, as a collection of gags it delivers. Uneven, certainly, and endlessly juvenile, but not as insufferable as the second one and not as endlessly vulgar as the actually alright original movie.6/10

Review title: Shows you can make a spoof film without resorting to filth.
Review_body: Scary Movie 3 (2003, Dir. David Zucker) A mysterious killer video tape is circulating around. One look at this tape and you have seven days left to live. News Reporter Cindy Campbell witnesses this video tape and tries to work out a way to prevent her death. But this is not the only mystery to appear. Crop circles have been appearing in the local farm of Tom and George. With help from Aunt Shaneequa, Cindy suspects that the aliens may be linked with the killer tape and must now work out both mysteries before it's the end of the world.They took a big risk when assigning the third instalment of the 'Scary Movie' series to David Zucker. It was obviously that fans of the filthy humour given by the Wayans will not be 100% pleased, but i feel that there is actually an improvement in the film than the previous two. The only two stars from the previous two films appearing in the second sequel was Anna Faris (Cindy Campbell) and Regina Hall (Brenda Meeks). Although the characters of them both have slightly changed, it's still a treat to have them in the film. Joining them is a whole host of stars including Queen Latifah, Charlie Sheen and Leslie Nielsen. All of them are a pleasure to see and they all look to be enjoying themselves. The story is very flexible just like the other spoof films, but has an outline which you can easily follow. I feel the jokes are a lot better. The previous two films really seems to rely on sex and filth jokes. The jokes in this film seem better constructed and are a lot more smarter. The only problem i have with this film is the amount of rap included. The rap contest wasn't bad but the film really could have done without the appearance of them all near the end."It was the chair." - Cindy (Anna Faris) "Yes, the chair." - Aunt Shaneequa (Queen Latifah)

Any way Scary Movie 3 brings you laughs and terror at the same time. I just wonder why such a low rating from the critics. Review title: A Disappointing Sequel but Still Mildly Enjoyable
Review_body: Scary Movie 3 isn't as funny as its predecessors but its still has its funny moments. It all begins when roving reporter Cindy Campbell sets out to find a hard news story in the middle of television sweeps. She soon uncovers an outrageous onslaught of globe-threatening developments including alien invaders, killer videotapes, freaky crop circles and much more. Faced with conspiracies of massive proportions, and a crew of very strange people following her around, Cindy must fight to stop evil from taking over the world yet again. The plot is a non-issue here as the first two were pretty much plot less. This time around they focus on Signs, The Ring, Matrix Reloaded and 8 mile as well as many others just not as much as the previously mentioned ones. The first one was {imo} one of the funniest films I have ever seen. The second one wasn't as good but still quite funny. The third one is mildly enjoyable but its nothing special. Let's just say that I didn't mind seeing it once but I probably wouldn't want to see it again. The jokes are either hit or miss and the ones that are funny usually involve Charlie Sheen. The lame ones usually involve Anthony Anderson as he is very overrated. Why he keeps getting cast is unclear because he isn't funny. Anna Faris gives a funny performance and she's also kind of underrated. Simon Rex shows some potential as he actually wasn't so bad. Regina Hall also returns as Brenda and she gives a pretty funny performance. The rest of the cast were pretty much a bunch of cameos. Jenny McCarthy and Pamela Anderson probably had the funniest scene out of all the cameos. Their in the opening sequence spoofing The Ring and that scene turns out to be on of the more enjoyable ones in the film. Denise Richards, Queen Latifah, Camryn Manheim and many others also have cameos. David Zucker directs and while this isn't another Airplane, it's also not another My Boss's Daughter either. Its pointless to really analyze a straight comedy as the main thing that people want to know if its funny or not. Like I said before if you do like it, you probably won't really like it that much. In the end, I found it a bit disappointing as the PG-13 rating kind of weaken it but it can still be enjoyed. Rating 6.3/10

Of course I liked the first two Scary Movies. They were hilarious. However, they were all just visual gags and disgusting toilet humour. In my opinion, it was a genius move having David Zucker take over for the Wayans Brothers because he's got a different style of humour...A style of humour that I find FAR funnier. Slapstick and word gags. David Zucker was responsible for the film Airplane! which is one of the greatest film comedies of all time, so I think it's great that he put his style into the Scary Movie franchise.The star power this time around is awesome. We've still got Cindy and Brenda, but now there's appearances by old comedy pros such as Leslie Nielsen and George Carlin. Even Charlie Sheen did a good job in this movie, even though he's not the best actor in the world. This Scary Movie is a spoof on Signs and The Ring, and the way they connect the two movies is genius.There's nothing much else I can say except the style of humour in this Scary Movie is SO much better than the first 2 and it's really refreshing to have a parody genius like Zucker take over for the over indulgent Wayans Brothers. This movie was the hardest I've laughed at a movie in a long time. Awesome.8/10

Review title: Hilarious spoof movie that doesn't deserve its low rating...
Review_body: ...now, all you pseudo film critics sipping your coffees thinking "'Scary Movie 3' is bad because it has no metaphors.  All the best spoofs have metaphors.  If someone were to like this, they'd have bad taste in film" are wrong.  Anyone who looks at my top 50 movies (including films like "Reservoir Dogs", "The Usual Suspects" and "12 Angry Men"...I'm 14) will know that I am far from having bad taste, and yet I liked this film. Perplexing isn't it?The answer is simple: "Scary Movie 3" is good.  The jokes, spoofs, gags, and just about everything else about this movie is hilarious.  And it would be, David Zucker made it.Some things I must point out: the spoofs about "the hood" and movie "8 Mile" were great.  I loved how it made fun of the popular cliches of every black person living Ghetto-lifestyles and owning guns.  After watching "Bringing Down the House" these jokes were a relief.Also, the spoofs of "Signs" and "The Matrix" are also quite hilarious.  They offer lines like "They mastered space travel and they don't know hoe to open a simple wooden door?" by Sheen's farmer and "I've been in this room for a long time with no one but myself and this chair; I call her...Linda" by a goofy Architect-like character from The Matrix Reloaded.So, if you're not too stuck up about film and you want to see a good funny movie, watch this, 7.5/10.

Review title: Doesn't Quite Have It But There Are Still Some Pretty Funny Scenes
Review_body: The Scary Movies are still a bit of classic's in my book but they should have stopped after two. Scary Movie 3 just didn't seem to have the same freshness and fun that the first two did. The film is a spoof of recent horror films such as Signs (2002), The Ring (2002) and for some odd reason The Matrix trilogy. They should have stuck to the original, no name cast instead of working in Charlie Sheen, Pamela Anderson, and Denise Richards. Pretty much they're trying to connect an odd video tape that kills people with an alien invasion. Simon Rex's character George is completely idiotic and stupid. He has no funny lines and is just plain moronic. He reminded me of Kelso from that 70's Show but just dumber. Charlie Sheen isn't exactly your top comedy actor but he does have a few good scenes especially the flashback spoof of Signs. You'll have some good laughs, some scenes are a bit dry and others just stupid. It doesn't compare to the first two but comes close. The language is cut down and the sexuality is minor. The spoofs aren't bad but some are over-used and Rex's performance mar every scene.Scary Movie 3. Starring: Charlie Sheen, Anna Faris, Simon Rex :-(, Pamela Anderson, and Leslie Nielson.2 1/2 out of 5 Stars.

Review title: Funny as well as Scary Movie 1 and 2!
Review_body: Genre: Horror/Comedy/MysteryRated PG-13 for Pervasive Crude and Sexual Humor, Language, Comic Violence and Drug ReferencesStar Rating: **** out of 5In this third installment of the Scary Movie franchise, Cindy Campbell (Anna Faris) is now out of college and is now a TV news anchorwoman. Strange things begin to occur when crop circles appear on Tom Logan's (Charlie Sheen) farm, but the suspense climaxes when Cindy's best friend Brenda (Regina Hall) dies an eerie death somehow relating to a killer video tape. After her nephew Cody watches the video tape, Cindy fears the lives of all and takes matters into her own hands, summoning the help of the Oracle (Queen Latifah) and Orpheus (Eddie Griffin) and visiting a infatuated Architect (George Carlin) on Curlesco Island. From this point on, Cindy uncovers the eerie link between the crop circles and the killer video tape, and must eventually assist the President of the United States (Leslie Nielsen) in a preventing alien invasion. My favorite parts were when in the beginning were they were spoofing The Ring and I think Lord of the Rings and Signs. I also liked the part were George (Simon Rex) and Mahalik (Anthony Anderson) were at Brenda's funeral and they might of over-heard saying that Brenda was alive and so then they do all of these things to try and bring her back and it doesn't work. I also liked a lot of the other funny parts. It was a major shame that Marlon Wayans and Shawn Wayans weren't in this third installment of the Scary Movie franchise because at that time they were busy with another movie. But they were the writing credits for this movie.BOTTOM LINE: I CAN'T STOP LAUGHING!

Review title: Hits your laughing muscles like a paint bucket
Review_body: "Scary Movie 3" is a horror comedy directed by David Zucker starring Anna Farris and Charlie Sheen. Without a doubt, every single cinephile out there has this one specific film that's their all time favourite guilty pleasure. From "Pootie Tang" to "Lara Croft: Tomb Raider" to almost any Adam Sandler feature there's at least one fan for every movie in the industry who loves it for how absolutely terrible it is. May it be the link to childhood memories or just the irresistible fascination for stupidity at times that leads us to this certain insanity, in every case they do exist. In my case, it's this absolutely trashy masterpiece (sarcasm!). I think I was around 13 years old when I watched it with my brother for the first time and although it's so bad, it became one of my favourites, to be honest. Even as of today, I'm laughing nonstop about the ridiculousness and inanity of the jokes. I think that's probably what makes it so charming. In an unimaginably silly way it parodies actually decent films I cherish, such as "8 Mile" and "Signs" and combines it with "The Ring" and it couldn't be any more dumb - still I love it. To this day, I'm still cracking up about the scene when he throws the bucket out of the car window and hits the biker or when Sheen wakes up and hits his head at the lamp (twice!). It's just the child in me that's extremely amused by it. It's overstated, at times way too loud and clearly foolish, but it still offers a great aspect: Leslie Freaking Nielsen as Mr. President. The man's pure comedy gold and he definitely delivers the greatest performance of the whole film, hands down. All in all, this movie is undoubtedly terrible and cheesy. The fact that it's my guilty pleasure doesn't change the obvious truth about it. It's so unimaginably bad that I love it and that's the only reason I own it on Blu-ray - otherwise I would have dumped it. But it's films like these that remind us that fun doesn't always have to result from high quality. Some films need to be watched by the child in us, so turn of your brain sometimes and embrace the embarrassment of cinematic disasters!
Again poking fun at era horror films, this movie had me laughing beginning to end!

Anna Faris, Charlie Sheen, Anthony Anderson, Leslie Nielsen, and so it goes on ... the list is long and impressive. There are a feast of quality comic actors, producing a genuinely funny movie. Given the talent on show it would be surprising if it wasn't funny, and unlike a lot of movie series Scary keeps on delivering the goods.The resemblance to Zucker's previous spoofs is obvious, and although I was very happy with Wayans' direction for 1 & 2 this isn't too different in style to be disappointing, and many may prefer the Airplane- & Naked Gun-style comedy. Sheen is a genius actor - much under-rated - and Anderson is always value for money - if a little stifled here. Cindy's prevalence towards open-mouthed astonishment does start to wear a little thin after 3 movies, but Anna is such a beautiful, talented and funny girl that I just don't care! I guess you either love or hate these movies, but for me there's never been a funnier series and I look forward to plenty more. Oh and did I mention, I love you Anna!

Scary Movie 3 came out in 2003,two years after the hilarious Scary Movie 2(2001). Review title: Finally Someone Got the Scary Movie Franchise to work
Review_body: Let me first start out by saying I think Scary Movie 1 & 2 are some of the worst movies I have ever seen. Now let me get to the good news Scary Movie 3 isn't as bad as the first 2. To be honest, Scary Movie 3 with a few scenes cut out could have possibly been one of the best spoofs to hit the cinema in years; however the editing doesn't happen.I for one was glad when the Wayans Brothers were off this project. I liked their work on In Living Color but they literally destroyed Scary Movie. The first movie had such a promising premise but they totally screwed it up. The second one was no different. The third one however has the spoof master David Zucker on board. David Zucker is responsible for some of my favorite comedies including Airplane, The Naked Gun Series, & BASEketball. This movie is no way as good as any of those movies but it tries really hard to be funny. The movie's whole ring & signs spoof was rather amusing and I did enjoy it. Some of the jokes in this film finally made me laugh because they went back to the normal spoof formula. However the spoof which I feel was way overused was the 8 mile spoof. First off this is a horror movie spoof so that shouldn't even be in the movie but its ok if it was in it for 5 minutes or so but the 8 mile part of the film took up a good 20 minutes or so of the film. This in my opinion made the movie seem to drag. I seen this movie with a theater packed full of people and it seemed that no one understood or laughed at the 8 mile portion of the film The movie had a decent cast including the funny Charlie Sheen, Anna Faris, & several others. Also a great performance by Leslie Nielsen who still has what it takes to make funny movies. David Zucker uses a lot of jokes from my favorite comedies which are mentioned above. There is a classic Airplane line which is used at the end of the movie. Well all in all for David Zucker's first attempt at Scary Movie he did a decent job recovering from what the Wayans Brothers did to the franchise. In this rare case, I feel that the scary movie series will keep getting better over time as long as David Zucker stays on as director, however if he leaves as a director then this franchise should be put to a end. All in all Scary Movie 3 is a huge improvement over the first 2 and has a lot of jokes that work but still lacks something that would make this be a great spoof. I applaud David Zucker for coming on this film and trying to bring back spoof movies. My final rating for Scary Movie 3 is a 6/10.

`Scary Movie 3' is an upgrade from the previous garbage that the Wayans Brothers brought us. Thankfully, we do not have to deal with their form of grotesque scenes, ridiculous marijuana jokes, or flagrant vulgarity. David Zucker has taken the reins as part writer and director. The director of such comedies as `Airplane,' and `The Naked Gun' brings with him an old school style at handling slapstick humor with jokes not based on grossing the audience out, but rather on simple high jinks. Although it becomes relentless at times, the film is ultimately far better than its predecessors. 	`Scary Movie 3' follows the story of Cindy (Anna Faris), now living in Washington DC, as she is taking care of her nephew Cody after the death of his parents.  Meanwhile, on a farm twenty miles away, a man named Tom (Charlie Sheen) wakes up to his daughter's scream and realizes that he has a crop circle that reads, `attack here.' Tom's brother George (Simon Rex), however, can not deal with the issue at hand, choosing only to focus on his rap career. He goes to Washington to perform in a rap battle where he quickly gets thrown out. Along the way he meets Cindy and the two become interested in each other, especially since Cindy is looking for a father to help her take care of Cody. But the two have bigger things to worry about-a potential alien invasion of earth. 	Like the previous `Scary Movie' flicks, this one focuses on spoofing horror films like `The Ring,' `Signs' and `The Others.' It also chooses to spoof recent blockbusters like `8 Mile' and `The Matrix Reloaded.' Here in lies the problem. It makes sense to try to spoof a horror flick, as there are so many these days. Yet trying to spoof several films is too much to handle and the plot suffers from not knowing where to go-an evident problem in films like `Spy Hard,' and `Wrongfully Accused.' In `Scary Movie 3,' the scene that relates to `8 Mile' is not necessary and it becomes tired before the main punch lines are uttered. 	To spoof a particular genre of films, focus on one and run with it. This is why films like `Hot Shots!' and it's sequel `Hot Shots: Part Deux' worked. They focused on the stories of `Top Gun' and `Rambo,' respectively. The same is true for the `Airplane' films as they focused on spoofing airline disaster flicks of the 70s. 	Is `Scary Movie 3' funny? Yes. I found myself laughing uncontrollably at times. This can be attributed to Leslie Nielsen's appearance as the President of the United States. Nielsen is a comic genius! His countenance comes off as serious, but his actions are totally silly. In one scene, he opens a door and knocks an alien down a well when Cindy and George were about to attack it. Without realizing his own dumb luck, he simply states in his classic line from `Airplane,' `I just want to tell you both good luck. We are all counting on you.' My initial response was to applaud. As far as movies go, it is the equivalent of sending Neil Armstrong into space a second time. 	We find a fair off-the-wall comedy in `Scary Movie 3.' At least parents do not have to worry about their kids sneaking into an R-rated feature anymore. `Scary Movie 3' is rated PG-13, the way its predecessors should have been designed for. Why target teenagers if you are going to make an R-rated feature? **1/2

Wow.You know, the first "Scary Movie" was a decent enough movie. It wasn't anything special, but it was alright. "Scary Movie 2" basically sucked, but it had its moments. Now here's "Scary Movie 3". It sure had a funny trailer. Of course, everybody knows these kinds of movies always put the best stuff in the trailer, but it's still probably gonna be kinda funny, right?Let me just say that "Scary Movie 3" makes the first two look like "The Godfather" and "The Godfather II". This movie is so bad I wanted to get up and punch the screen.Let me save you the money and demonstrate what it does for 90 minutes of audience torture: "Hey! This part's like 'The Ring'! This part's like 'Signs'! This part's like '8 Mile'! This part's like 'The Matrix'!" That's it. We recognize parts of those other movies, but the writers apparently thought that was enough, because they do NOTHING with them.Oh wait, this is what it's ACTUALLY like: "Hey! This part's like 'Signs'! Except someone gets kicked in the crotch!". Sigh.Here's the (only) good stuff: the opening scene, with Jenny McCarthy and Pamela Anderson. There's about 3 good laughs in it. Then there's a throwaway gag about pop-up ads later on (that's actually the funniest part, but it's only about 3 seconds long).The only genuine redeeming quality, though, as in all 3 of the "Scary Movie" films, is Anna Faris. She's a gifted and charming actress, and I'm glad she's popping up in some quality films, like "May" and "Lost In Translation". Hopefully she'll still have a career long after "Scary Movie 3" is gathering dust in the dollar bin at the video store.

Review title: In ten years time, the only Scary Movie I will gladly watch again will be this one.
Review_body: As far as these not-so-groundbreaking comedies go, the third part is easily the one most shock-full of funny stupidity and the one that stands up to repeated viewings. It is the most quotable of the four and the one with the best story and characters, like that's saying much. But the bottom line is that the film is hilarious. It never lags behind and it always has another dumb joke, sight gag, reference or annoying kid being hit by a car up its sleeve. Unlike the first movie, where only the few scattered moments of cleverness were really funny, or the second which was stupid and lamely written like the writers' crystal meth intake depended on it, "3" has an abundance of dumb jokes - and almost all of them work! This can all be attributed to David Zucker, who does anything but live up to his name and shows really great comic timing. Without this, the entire script would be excruciating, but Zucker's clever direction (how many noticed Cindy jumping at the loud noise from a boat - coming from a different scene?) and the cast's talent make the film much funnier than it has any right to be. Call it a guilty pleasure or comedy gold, either way, unless you're one of those people who watches Richard Gere movies on purpose, this movie will leave you breathless with laughter. The movie has enough celebrity cameos to fill your average episode of "The Simpsons", a cast ranging from photogenic eye candy in the form of Pamela Anderson and Jenna McCarthy to in-need-of-a-hit actors like Leslie Nielsen, Charlie Sheen and Anna Faris, and even a little rap music to boot (and to please the 11-year old, 50 Cent-loving, white suburban kids). The film is not ugly to look at, and the various different visual styles and moods of the movies spoofed are well re-created, like the gritty, washed-out photography of the "8 Mile" sequences or the oh-so-ominous music in the "Ring" segments. The cast works well together; few people can keep a straight face muttering ridiculous dialogue like Charlie Sheen and who can play a dumb blond better than Anna Faris? Vertically challenged, leg-humping Kevin Hart steals the show, although "the dogs are acting strange" is classic.Of course this kind of comedy is anything but timeless, since most of the movies spoofed will be forgotten as time goes by, but we teenagers who were born in the late eighties to early nineties will forever hold this quadrilogy of stupidity dear to our hearts. Definitely more entertaining than its victims - the ridiculously pretentious "Ring" (2002), the lackluster mess "Matrix Reloaded" (2003), or even "8 Mile" (2002) (which I actually liked) - "Scary Movie 3" is one of my favourite comedies and, in my humble opinion, one of the funniest spoofs ever made. Laugh all you want. I am.

You won't be disappointed either as these are both good movies and much better than Scary Movie 3 anyway.  Second, expect to see a dip in the "creative genius" of the Wayans brothers as the movie isn't a satire for as many other movies as the prequels were.  Maybe you can blame it on a deprivation in source material as of late, but I don't think so.  The ending is...well...lame.  And as such leaves you walking away with the feeling the rest of the movie was shoddy. But not to be too critical, I did heartily laugh at several skits and appreciated the humor involved.  Again, just don't expect as much insanely funny comedy as Scary Movie 1 or 2.

Review title: Better than the second, but a lot of things are
Review_body: *1/2 out of (****)After the abysmal wreck that was "Scary Movie 2", my faith, rather than being restored, had been crushed for "Scary Movie 3". And usually, the third in the franchise is where it starts to dip in quality. It turns out this was an improvement over 2001's train wreck, but a lot of things are. Jokes are limited because of a more teen-oriented rating, characters are missing, and less boundaries are pushed. That's a fancy way of saying this can't be good. And it isn't. However, I do give the director some props. With what was handed to him, he put forth the best intentions. But no matter the effort, when your film sucks, it sucks. First of all, what went right? The leads that did return still gave great performances and still retained the charm they had in the preceding films. It's always good to see those familiar faces again. Not to mention, the film is eccentric and is always packed with energy. Let's just say, you won't be bored. And also, the jokes weren't too bad. There were some that worked.Now, what went wrong? Pretty much everything else. I felt that since that over-the-top gross out factor was absent, the slapstick element became the norm. A tip for filmmakers: Never resort to slapstick. It's not funny, and only serves as a distraction. Not to mention, the fans are torn because the original cast isn't back. What made the original powerful was all of the performers. When some of them are missing, the film just isn't the same. With a title like Scary Movie 3, your expectations certainly aren't going anywhere, and if they are, they better not be high. I will give it that the film has its moments, but that's why Youtube was invented. Stick with a rental folks.

After seeing the shorts of this - it looked like a bit of a return to form for the scary movies BUT when you watch it and realise that the funniest jokes (or should that be joke - singular?) were (or was) on the trailer!Apparently - the Wayans brothers who were responsible for the first two - were nowhere to be seen in this instalment and I think it shows. Also - Signs was a very weird choice for a spoof - the original movie (in my opinion) wasn't all that memorable - so why a spoof a few years later? The 8 Mile spoof was incredibly tedious!My opinion - do not go and see this film! It is terrible - even worse than Scary Movie 2 (which seems like high art compared to Scary Movie 3). Shocking stuff!

Review title: The same flavor of immature humor.
Review_body: Despite the departure of the Wayans brothers from the franchise and a cast overflowing with comedic talent, "Scary movie 3" still offers the same kind of obvious, disgusting and low brow humor we have come to expect from these movies. Much like it's predecessors, this third instalment has a few solid laughs, but it focuses a lot more on satirizing movies that were popular at the time and making as many immature and unimaginable jokes as possible without trying to take the franchise any further in terms of comedy, making the audience feel like the filmmakers are just testing their patience at this point.

Put the name "Wayans" on it and I walk out of the theater (if ambushed), or change the channel. The Wayans are a brand name in Hollywood that can greenlight anything they want, but the traffic laws should be rewritten to prevent this. Fortunately, none of the Ws returned for this film.I did not see either of the first two films of this trilogy, but you really don't need to know the story to enjoy this film, since the plot of any good parody is just an excuse to deliver the maximum number of spoofs, gags, swipes, and one-liners by the end of the film. In that regard, this film does not disappoint.Anna Faris (Cindy Campbell) is a surprisingly strong and exceptionally hot leading lady who should be considered for any A-list roles in the future. She did everything asked of her and then some, and the sky appears to be the limit for her talent. Cindy is a reporter for a Newscast that brings to life the song "Dirty Laundry" by Don Henley (she's the bubbleheaded bleached blond who comes on at 5:00 and tells you about the plane crash with a gleam in her eye). Charlie Sheen plays a former reverend who lost faith after his hot wife was killed in an accident (again, they even made that funny).Anthony Anderson is excellent in his supporting role, while the rest of the cast could have been chosen by lottery, other than Leslie Neilsen, who seems to have a contract somewhere that says a parody can't be made without him (he plays the president in this one). George Carlin makes a creepy cameo, as does Eddie Griffin and Queen Latifah, but the stars of the movie are the jokes, and they come rapid-fire.The film was designed for an intelligent audience in tune with pop culture, and doesn't take time to explain itself: Simon Cowell gets to judge an 8-mile style rap battle with predictable and hilarious results; Anderson's character sheds more light on the possible depths of the relationship between B. Rabbit and Future; Leslie Neilsen gets to deliver a classic line from "Airplane" at one point, while showing that he's kept up with the times in another. The newsroom was more realistic than most would admit or want to believe, and the way the horror was delivered in this film (yes, it's a genuine horror movie) was a "Scream." We even get a nod to Final Destination (one of the most original concepts of all time), and at times the movie even seems to parody itself.If you liked "Airplane!" and its genre, there's little chance you won't like this film. If you can't stand that type of humor, get ready to tear your hair out. For better or worse, this film belongs in a time capsule to explain what a movie parody is and how it should be made.

When I first heard that David Zucker was directing this movie, I was ecstatic.  This is the guy who brought us "Airplane," the "Naked Gun" movies and even "Ruthless People"--which I consider to be one of the funniest comedies of all time.  Did it live up to my expectations?  Not quite.  Just like a lot of comedies that have come out recently, it's another collection of stale, predictable gags.  I did laugh at spots--hell, I was trying to get my money's worth.  But for a Zucker film, I expect a lot funnier.  I don't expect every single gag having to do with either someone getting hit in the head or children getting hit by cars.  Since the film is PG-13, there's not as much room for the raunchiness that pervaded throughout parts 1 and 2, but in place we have nothing but cheap slapstick.  The other movies were funny, but funny in a way that you laugh your butt off the first time, but by the second viewing the jokes have already run dry.  After all, the Wayans aren't known for their large wits.  So I was waiting to badmouth this film and go on about how David Zucker knows how to handle the spoof genre, while the Wayans don't.  But in fact, the Wayans have handled the genre better.  At least I got some laughs out of the first two films.  The only two returning members from the first two movies are Anna Faris and Regina Hall.  The latter I don't mind, though she's no Lucille Ball, but Faris is a terrible comic actress.  I don't know why I'm reading posts on message boards, saying that she has real talent and she'll move onto bigger and better things.  I already came to conclusion, after watching the original "Scary Movie," that her timing and delivery was totally off.  She has the beauty, but that's all she's got.  So for all you women who think guys will regard any beautiful actress as "good," you're sorely mistaken--or at least you can exclude me.  Meanwhile, women regard Vin Diesel as a good actor, yet he couldn't slap on a facial expression if his life depended on it--but that's drifting into another issue.  The rest of the cast is quite talented, but they seem to be there simply to add on more star power.  It's one of those films where there are cameos for the sake of cameos.  They're simply there so the young ones can go "Ooooh, that's Master P" or "Ooooh, that's Ja Rule."  Leslie Nielsen has a small and unfortunately thankless role.  After the "Naked Gun" movies he has drifted into oblivion, which is really a shame because he's truly a comic genius.  Charlie Sheen has shown his knack for comedy in past films like "Hot Shots" and "Major League," but he is also wasted in this movie.  He appears totally embarrassed to be in this movie, and looks almost like he's playing a caricature of himself. 
So don't get suckered--or should I say Zuckered--in like me.  This is less on the scale of "Airplane" and "The Naked Gun," and more on the scale of "Baseketball" and "My Boss' Daughter"--other mediocre flicks directed by Zucker.  If you want to see all the funny gags, just watch the trailer.  As a matter of fact, the "I am Morpheus" gag with Eddie Griffin with him saying "I am prophesizing" and Queen Latifah as his wife responding with "I'm gonna prophesize my foot up your a**" isn't even in the movie!  Is it a scheme to lure audiences into buying the DVD (with the deleted scenes)?  Maybe. 
My score:  5 (out of 10)

The Good: This is the best Scary Movie of them all. It is a hidden gem, lost because critics - in their most 2000s of ways - looked down upon this franchise and prejudged this one too. Is it a masterpiece? No. Is it smart? No. It's crude, it's stupid, it's juvenile...it's funny as hell.What separates SM3 from the rest is how the PG-13 completely shifted the comedic tone of this movie. Yes, you have your sex and bodily humour jokes. But you also have incredibly clever visual gags, slapstick humour, puns, turns of phrase and legitimately funny observations about the movies this one skewers.Speaking of which, choosing to basically meld the plot of Signs and The Ring together (with a couple references to other movies here and there) was the best structure of the entire series. While what happens is nonsensical, it's a legitimate story structure that ends at the right place in a natural way. I see that as an upgrade.The cast is clearly having a blast here and this movie is just ELECTRIC with the energy. It transports you into this kooky, funny cartoony world where anything can happen. I wholeheartedly recommend this one. Honestly.The Bad: I mean, what can I say that's truly "bad" here? It looks cheap? Yes. It's juvenile? Yes. It sometimes goes overboard with the pop culture references? Yes. Yadda yadda, critics had a field day with this one 18 years ago.The Ugly: While Scary Movie (and "parody") movies persisted after SM3, honestly, this one is on another level of funny. It just GETS its source material and knows what it's doing to parody them. I can't say that for almost any of the other movies or imitators.

Review title: A genuinely dumb, yet funny movie!

(Yet, we have Lord of the Rings part 3, which is fantastic and American Wedding, so maybe I lied!)This movie is less sexually oriented than the first, but it has plenty of low-brow humor in it still, and it's well worth watching.Perhaps wait for it on DVD, as it isn't very long and if you're going to pay $10 to see a movie, you should at least see Cold Mountain or The Last Samurai where you'll get value for your $1!

Review title: What? A "Scary Movie" that's actually funny? Say it's not so!
Review_body: Many movie critics bent over backwards to heap tons of praise on the original "Scary Movie," a film that I felt was as funny as getting a root canal. In contrast, "Scary Movie 3" has received mostly negative reviews from the same critics who liked the original, despite being a much funnier movie.During the course of 90 minutes of silliness, "American Idol" judge Simon Cowell is ventilated by gunfire after giving a negative review to a rap battle, Michael Jackson (or a reasonable facsimile) is dangled over a balcony while the man holding him says "How do YOU like it?" and a news room bursts into a spontaneous football party a la a Coors Light commercial. Comedy is subjective, and instances like these will either attract viewers like flies or turn them away in droves.Television anchorwoman Cindy Campbell (Anna Faris) seeks to investigate a mysterious crop circle pattern in a Virginia farm cornfield. At the same time, her good friend Brenda Meeks (Regina Hall) tells her about a killer videotape that she has seen that supposedly curses the viewer via a phone call to die seven days later. Cindy watches the tape and gets the phone call, realizing she has a week to find a way to stop the supernatural killer from striking.The owner of the farm, Tom Logan (Charlie Sheen), is a former minister having a crisis of faith following the unfortunate death of his wife. Meanwhile, his brother George (Simon Rex) dreams of becoming a rapper and hopes to hook up with Cindy, whose psychic son has Brenda as a teacher along with Tom's daughter. Circumstances force them all to join forces to discover the connection between the videotape and a possible alien invasion.If you haven't guessed, the plot is a mix between "Signs" and "The Ring" with "8 Mile" thrown in haphazardly for good measure. The storyline is a threadbare at best, just an excuse to poke fun at the latest box office thrillers with a general vibe of goofiness and satire. In terms of coherent story telling, the movie is a train wreck, but as an exercise in throwing funny things up on screen, the jokes arrive right on schedule.What sets this film apart from the two previous movies in this series is perhaps the mindset in general. "Scary Movie" and "Scary Movie 2" were both R-rated envelope pushers, showing disgusting sex-related physical jokes never-before-seen in movie theaters. Comedy, however, has always been in the suggestion of naughtiness, and not the actual presentation of it. The PG-13 rating here holds the movie within a general safe bound, keeping the filmmakers under control and forcing the humor to focus on funny line delivery, not gross bodily functions.Not that "Scary Movie 3" skimps on all bodily functions, but at least it's nothing repugnant this time.Director David Zucker, whose credits in this genre include co-directing "The Naked Gun" and "Airplane!" is certainly a much more accomplished director than the series' previous helmer Keenan Ivory Wayans. His scenes do not drag on to the point of exhaustion though they still could have benefited from more editing in some cases. Camera action is more lively this time out too, as opposed to the static movement in the first two films.Acting here is not outstanding, but it gets the job done considering the circumstances. Returning for the third time, Faris has not improved her supposed thespian skills one iota from the first film. She's still the same brainless character who has no business surviving a horror movie besides for being the main character.Sheen just goes through the motions, neither quite satisfying nor upsetting viewer expectations. He really isn't the right type to be spoofing Mel Gibson's nuanced performance, but he does deliver his goofy lines with the appropriate straight face.Cameos and other small roles abound here to various degrees of success, including spoof king Leslie Nielsen as the President, who steals practically every scene he's in with little effort. Queen Latifah, Eddie Griffin and George Carlin all show up parodying characters from "The Matrix Reloaded," though it's obvious all their scenes where written quickly to cash in on that film and lack any other true purpose or meaning in this movie.Where "Scary Movie 3" ultimately fails though is ironically in the same department as the first two movies. What made "Airplane!" and "The Naked Gun" so great, as well as pre-Zucker spoofs like "Monty Python and the Holy Grail" and "Blazing Saddles," is that all those films parodied entire genres and not just specific films.All three "Scary Movie" films take the easy route by attacking current blockbusters, just like every spoof movie since "Spy Hard" has. Unfortunately, what is funny now will not be funny three years from now. The horror genre has so many conventions ripe for satire that it's a shame that "Scary Movie 3" seeks mediocrity in an already overcrowded market.Seven out of ten stars. Lacks the motivation and ability to become a classic, but still a fun romp on the old theater. You should probably wait until video to see it though.

Review title: The Moose Hole - Review of Scary Movie 3
Review_body: Boo! Did that scare you? Maybe the large amount of horror releases this year did. It is just amazing how quickly the American public can go from a period after September 11th when all slasher flicks were deemed insensitive to the present day when two R-rated blood fests are tops at the weekend box office. It's also amazing to see how quickly the spoof film could go from being a hot commodity to just plain leftovers. Though the genre was invented long before the original Scary Movie, this horror spoof regenerated the failing genre when it grossed $157 million by the end of its run in 2000. A year later Scary Movie 2 opened to a less then stellar $71 million end but enough money was made to deem it a success and green light another sequel. But now the third film in the series may be the bottom of the barrel as it has had a difficult road to completion with the creators of the franchise dropping out and several false production starts. Will Scary Movie 3 fail at the box office? Not likely with the low production budget, effective marketing campaign, and enough product placement to cover any a bit of those costs. Then why is this considering the low end of the stick? You have to admit that the story or lack there of can't get worse.The story . Well, there really isn't one except for the fact that it spoofs films like The Matrix Reloaded, The Ring, The Others, and Signs. But besides that fact, there is some small plot trying to squeak through. Cindy Campbell, now fresh from college, gets her first big break as a TV news reporter when strange crops circles appear in the corn fields of farmer Tom Logan. In her investigation, she also discovers a videotape that kills its viewers seven days after they watch it and her nephew is one of them. Cindy is now called up by the president to help prevent an alien invasion and stop of the deaths cause by the mysterious tape. The story for Scary Movie 3, like it was said before, really doesn't exist but when is this never case with any spoof film? Bottom-line is that the third installment in the horror-spoof franchise is less consistent with its weak plot then the other two films but it comes to these films, you just have to leave your head at the door. For some movie-goers, that can be easier said then done.There are plenty of prominent performers in this cast but most of them are mere cameos then featured roles. Anna Faris once again appears as Cindy Campbell in the spoof franchise. She obviously has the comedic talent for these types of films but if she doesn't get out of things sooner or later, she'll be stuck in these roles for the rest of her career. That would be quite unfortunate because Faris clearly has the talent to branch out into other genres. Charlie Sheen and Denise Richards appear, if not briefly, together in the film but it is Sheen who gets the bigger role. The biggest laughs of the film came from him especially his battle with Michael Jackson (or at least, a decent look-alike). The biggest disappointments came from Queen Latifah and Eddie Griffin, who play the Oracle and Orpheus. It wasn't their performances but their lack of appearance in the film that left many unsatisfied. The two are promoted pretty decently in the trailers and television ads yet they appear less then ten minutes in the entire film. Miramax should ashamed! The opening sequence featuring Pamela Anderson and Jennie McCarthy is just pathetic and borders on the line of stupid funny and just plain stupid. There are many blondes in the world that resent the `dumb blonde' comments . They must be on the verge of killing these two. Not one bit of their sequence is funny and showcases they can't act even in a spoof feature that doesn't require much acting in the first place.Overall, Scary Movie 3 scares the movie-going audience for all the wrong reasons. Will there ever be an intelligent spoof film or is that just another pipe dream? Not to say that the film is not funny, it is a large improvement from the last Scary Movie feature, but there has to be a better way to get laughs then relentless slap-stick that gets more annoying then some of the films it tries to spoof. The running over of the kid got repetitive quickly and many of the sequences featuring it could have been ditched. One scene that got a little too provocative featured Darrell Hammond as a priest who baby-sits Cindy Campbell's nephew. Though there are many out there who are not Catholic, there are plenty who will find the sequence insensitive and mean-spirited. In fact, the entire feature is mean-spirited but manages to crack off a few decent laughable moments to make the film all the less tolerable. If you want intelligent filmmaking, effective humor, a stellar cast, a believable story, and a memorable time at the movies then this is not your film by a long shot. Scary Movie 3 requires nothing of the audience but to leave their heads at the door much like the filmmakers themselves.My Rating: *** out of 5 (Grade: C-)

Review title: Best of All Scary Movies. I Loved It Very Much !!!
Review_body: I was eager to watch this movie when I saw it previews, but I had few doubts. The previous Scary movies were good but were cheap at heart for giving stupid jesters with adult matters. I got irritated while watching it in front of my family. But when it came to 3rd chapter, it's a whole different story.Scary Movie 3 (Spoilers******) Based on the characters created by Wayans brothers the Scary Movie series takes a new turn when it took up by the acclaimed director of the cult comedies, David Zucker. Like his previous works he gives a respected look to the rude comedy by transforming the sexual offensive teenage movie into a family enjoyable humor. That makes this movie the best one in the Scary franchise.Teenage Cindy (innocent Anna Faris) is now grown up, she is working as a news reporter in a TV channel. Not satisfied about her current status she wanted to do some important stories like strange crop circles recently appeared on a farmer's corn field. Even taking care of her best friend's child, Cindy is not seeking for any relationship. But things are going to be peppy when she meets up with a young rapper George (onscreen portrayal wise a carbon clone of Eminem, Simon Rex).Anna Faris rocked as mature Cindy but the real star in the movie was David Zucker, he marked his signature again, it's pretty funny to watch such unrelated silly things on background when the story goes. With a dream cast of top celebrities including Pamela Anderson, Charlie Sheen, Anthony Anderson, Simon Cowell, Fat Joe, Queen Latifah, Ja Rule and DENISE RICHARDS, Zucker created another Naked Gun movie! I always loved his works.And last but not least, How can be David Zucker movie without the Superman Leslie Nielsen! I was missed SUPERSTAR Leslie Nielsen for a long time and he just came back in his younger days by this movie. Nielsen rocked as American President.It's good the Wayans brothers didn't take part in the movie, if that happened it should have Sucked. Due to their absence and the presence of master of spoof cinema David Zucker, Scary Movie 3 is the best hilarious movie to DATE! Best wishes for his upcoming 4th Scary Movie!"I give this movie 10 out of 10!"

Review title: Despite the second movie...you will laugh to dead with this one
Review_body: First of all, once you are entering the movie theater or switching on your DVD player, you must get rid off the first two movies. The first movie was like the project made by two film students with some good performers, a retarded screenplay and sex-shop stuff. The second movie was like a no-sense of gags based in famous box-office movies of the moment and a quite impossible to forget gag of Nike Basketball advertisement. This movie is what Scary Movie should be from the beginning. A David Zucker film. Every gag has it's explanation, and well, at least all of them are really funny, or near from the hysterical laugh. And the best of all, it focuses on four movies (Matrix reloaded, The ring, 8 mile and Signs) and it joins all of them with a powerful screenplay, because yeah, this movie has the best screenplay of the trilogy. About plot? No. About funny and laughs? Oh yeah! The girl of the Ring trapped under the house of Signs where the guy of 8 mile lives? My god!!! Why I didn't have that idea before? The Architech being spanked and ridiculed? Yes please please please!!! Show me more of the green old man. The crazy and shocked kid of The Ring transformed into a target for bumps, hits and punches? Yeah! Kick in the crotch? Yeah! Charlie Sheen? Yeah! Leslie Nielsen? Oh boy, this is too much for me! yeah yeah yeah!!!

Review title: The best Scary Movie so far.
Review_body: I was really looking forward to seeing this movie as I enjoyed the first two movies. When I saw the trailer I knew it was going to be good. I have now seen it twice and it has become my favorite movie in the series. This is one of the best screw ball comedies that I have seen. It has funny jokes, great one liners, funny characters and many movies combined in a funny way to make a crazy "plot". The only fault I can think of is that they maybe used too many slapstick jokes. I hope the next movie will be even better if that's possible.

by Dane Youssef"Scary Movie 3" marks the end of an era. The first was a funny romp, worthy of the Zuckers (and Abrhams) and the Farrelys.The entire Wayans clan coming together, roasting popular movies like franks on a bonfire. Gay, sh*t, dick, pee, cum and retard jokes galore. It was near brilliant.The best part of it was that it was a collage of stupidity, cleverness, goofiness, vulgarity and pop culture, like the Wayans' "In Living Color," the first "Scary Movie" proves that the Wayans' are a tribe of talent.The second in the series, "Scary Movie 2" (after promising there would be no sequel-- Marlon was quoted as saying, "We sold out. The offered us money and we jumped at the chance"), opened with a premise so brilliant and so hilarious, the movie could never live it down.The ingenious opening on "The Exorcist" before the opening credits with James Woods and Andy Richter was a legendary moment in comedy. "The Exorcist" has been spoofed countless times before (many, many times before... but I can honestly say, never this well. The way it's written, the way it's directed, the way it's played, the way it's planned... this movie achieves some kind of feat for building so much out of such an over-worked premise. That one opening sequence almost makes the movie at least worth renting."Scary Movie 3" is largely a fault of the studio. The house has been brought down, the curtain calls have been had... but Miramax just won't find a new franchise. It's just so sad. Everything, EVERYTHING that was once good and pure is no long gone. Even the Wayans themselves. Zucker is just back doing what he does best... or maybe just often. This is his invention and no one does it better than him, but maybe the problem is the machine-gun spoof (called so because jokes fire on automatic like out of an automatic gun) has just been run into the ground. Maybe the problem is that this movie just wants to goof and imitate and and laugh to itself whereas the original "Scary Movie" (and a lot of Zucker's earlier stuff) was directly there to attack.You can tell from the ads alone that this will not be a funny movie. Everyone steps up, references big hits and then makes fun. Not in an attacking sort of way, but just acts goofy and silly. They're all just having fun, not making fun.And because it's directly from the co-inventor of this entire genre, he brings his own people to the table. Leslie Neilsen, Jenny McCarthy and many of the instruments that he used since he started out.You know, it's so funny and strange. MAD magazine can do this forever. SNL... well, USED to be able to do this, but it now it seems like SNL should close down itself. For some reason, some spoof artists can just keep going till' the drop. Others should just cash in their chips and quit while they're ahead. No sense in beating a single note together.The problem with "Scary Movie 3" is the same thing that's wrong with Miramax and perhaps even David Zucker. These people don't seem to realize it's time to move on. That it's over. They're beating a dead horse. Trying to milk a dead cow. The Wayans have moved on. Zucker, Miramax and we should, too.I look foreword to their next endeavors in art and life, whatever they may be. Their stretching, but this is like an old once-hipster jacket that has been worn down to a few threads. Enough already. Remember when the Itallion Stallion didn't know when to throw in the towel."Do you like 'Scary Movies?'"Not anymore.It's over.SPECIAL NOTE: Legendary screenwriter Kevin Smith, rumored to be one of the finest scribes in all of Hollywood is credited with this screenplay. What a dent in the armor. He's rumored to be difficult to work with. Maybe he just works better alone. I hope he sticks to solo projects, this and "Coyote Ugly"... no wonder he doesn't work well with others.--An Ex-Lover Of Scary Movies, Dane Youssef

Review title: Turn your brain off and have a good time.
Review_body: Objectively, this is a terrible movie, and the sense of humor is really dumb. However, I cannot deny it's really really funny. This movie was a laugh riot when I was a kid, and believe it or not I actually found it even funnier on rewatch as an adult. I laughed really hard, way harder than I should have at a lot of the old jokes I remembered and new ones I never noticed before. It's hard to get a real involuntary laugh out of me, and I involuntarily burst out laughing 10 or 15 times, which is a lot for me. Assigning a numerical score is hard; it's a 3 in terms of objective quality, but an 8 or 9 in terms of entertainment value, so I'll meet somewhere in the middle and give it a 5/10. If you're a fan of stupid humor and just want to turn your brain off and have a good time alone or with friends, this movie'll do the job.

Scary Movie 3: This time around, aim is taken at such horror blockbusters as Signs and The Ring, while films of other genres, including Independence Day, 8 Mile, and The Matrix, are also lampooned. The plot finds Cindy Campbell (Anna Faris) trying to help the president (Leslie Nielsen) thwart an alien attack while also facing crop circles and a mysterious video tape. That is basically the plot summary in a nutshell.Well... all I can say about Scary Movie 3 is that it's the most gut bustingly hilarious, laugh your ass off movie I have ever seen in my entire life!! This movie is genius!! I have never been so impressed with a comedy in my life. It made me laugh so much that I was in tears by the end. I was laughing so hard during the wake scene that I almost fainted!! I was feeling very light headed after the wake scene was over.

"Scary Movie 3" is, in my opinion, the best out of the series. It is so much funnier than the other two and the gags are better. Of course this film isn't great by any means, but it still really funny. From Charlie Sheen waking up in bed and hitting his head on the lamp, not once, but twice, to the little Ring girl coming out of the TV and leaning over to get the water out of her ears. The humor was much better written in this film too. The jokes were funnier and the actors were funnier. I like the first two Scary Movies, but this one just has all the better jokes. Jeremy Piven was great in a couple of scenes as news anchor Ross Giggins. I thought it was so funny when Cindy, her boss, and the black janitor were fighting over the teleprompter and Ross was reading everything that was on it. And the black janitor wrote "I've been hitting it with Giggins' woman for ten years. She likes her some chocolate" and Ross is just reading away, not even realizing what he said. I thought that was one of the funniest scenes in the movie. Charlie Sheen was great as the farmer Tom. I normally don't consider him funny but he was perfectly cast in this film. Besides Anna Faris as Cindy, of course, I thought the character of George was the funniest character in this film. I mean, what's funnier than a redneck white guy trying to be a black rapper? It's so funny because he doesn't realize just how bad he really is. I laughed till I had tears in my eyes. "Scary Movie 3" isn't a great film by any means but it's definitely the funniest out of all the Scary Movie films. I think this one is even better than #4. The jokes and humor just work in this film. Sure this film won't win any awards but it will definitely put a smile on your face, especially if you're a fan of slapstick humor, like I am. Thank you for reading my review!

In the Scary Movie franchise, you have to turn your brain off when entering the theater. This third entry is no different, although it has been dialed down to a PG-13 level to attract a younger audience. This made me extremely skeptical when going to see this, but since it had Charlie Sheen, I gave it a chance, and I'm glad I did. The first Scary Movie had a few scenes where I cried, I was laughing so hard. The second didn't quite reach that level, but was a decent enough time-passer. This entry has a couple of monstrous laughs, and constant chuckles throughout. It's consistently funny, although some of the jokes miss completely, there are so many gags it's barely even noticeable. The special effects are terrible, but it doesn't matter here.One thing I really like about this movie, is that there are so many familiar faces in the cast. Of course, Anna Faris and Regina Hall return, added to the cast are Charlie Sheen, Leslie Nielsen, Anthony Anderson, George Carlin, Queen Latifah, and Eddie Griffin. It's fun to see so many good actors come together in a silly meaningless comedy like this.Even though it's dialed down in terms of crude sex jokes, this movie isn't any less funny than the first, and hands down, it's way better than the second. 7/10

Aliens III, Lethal Weapon III, Matrix Revolutions, Return of the Jedi, Scream III, all these movies have something in common: they are the weakest of a trilogy (keep in mind that Star Wars was once a trilogy).It seems the people behind these films ran out of the ideas they had for the first two in the series. Scary Movie III, however, seems to be a rare exception. Maybe because the first two Scary Movies weren't that good to begin with.In Scary Movie III, the Wayans brother seem to have exploited the good things about the first two: lots of people getting punched, hit with bats, cars, etc, people being stupid, stumbling, etc. And of course, making fun of horror and science fiction films. Last but not least, they seem to have realized that some people don't find disgusting scenes funny at all.This film has a lot of scenes that can make you laugh as long as you like spoof films. The funeral scenes is one of the best I have ever seen. Then there is the alien footage scenes. And the unforgettable scenes mocking the Matrix series.
Many films of this type have been terrible. Mafia, for example, made me leave the theater, and I hadn't done that before, no matter how bad the movie was. Not Another Stupid American Movie was beyond stupid and made me wonder if it was time to stop making this type of films. Scary Movie has revitalized them.

Review title: Better than the second movie but worse than the first
Review_body:
It's the early 2000s parody formula. All you need is to base the story on few recent and successful high budget movies, make fun of everything and everyone in the most ridiculous ways, have action/horror which mostly leads to comedy, sexy girls and everything else you would expect from a parody.It's a time capsule for anyone who wants to go back to the early days and remember all iconic situations and characters of the movie which aren't that many in this movie compared to the first one.The story is as cliché as you would expect from a parody movie, and it's kinda enjoyable after all these years.
Cliché story, music, effects, and the amazing 2000s vibe works kinda well.Overall I think quite a lot of people will not enjoy it and quite a portion will. Personally, after watching the original movie this feels like not the greatest parody and not the worst one, it's somewhere in the middle around 6 out of 10. It's better than the second movie but worse than the first one.
Would kinda recommend to anyone familiar or not with parodies, but it wouldn't be my first choice at all.

The movie leaves a bad taste in your mouth.  There were several very random funny parts throughout the movie but most are just ridiculous.  I understand that the jokes from the others were ridiculous as well,  but at least they were funny.  You can only watch people get punched, hit, kicked, knocked down, so many times before it stops being funny, and this movie does it about twenty too many times. As far as spoof comedies go, Scary Movie 3 isn't terrible, but it certainly isn't good either. It's a huge improvement over the awful second film in the franchise, but it fails to deliver enough laughs to be able to recommend it.The film delivers a few laughs here and there thanks to a few surprisingly clever jokes and slapstick bit, but it feels like the writers went for too many cheap jokes and slapstick humor. The two main parodies are Signs and The Ring which the film does an alright job of poking fun at, but there is a lot of wasted opportunity in poking fun of these films as well. One of the problems with the last film as that it parodied films that weren't even part of the horror genre and these moments felt rather forced and out of place than funny. This film suffers from that problem as well parodying 8 Mile and The Matrix. Neither of these moments are funny nor clever and feel like a cheap attempt to parody other recent films that were popular at the time of release. This wouldn't be a problem if the film was not suppose to be a spoof of horror films and these moments weren't taking away screen time that could have been used to poke fun at the films part of the actual genre it's suppose to be spoofing. Anna Faris was alright in the lead, but I was really disappointed by how underused Charlie Sheen was.Scary Movie 3 isn't terrible compared to a lot of other spoof movies out there. It does have a couple of funny moments, but the laughs are far in-between a great deal of cheap jokes and tired slapstick humor to be able to recommend it.

I liked the spoof of the Ring better than I liked the movie "The Ring", which I really disliked due to the child abuse of the little girl.Some reviewers have gotten upset about the little boy being hit by a car several times, so I thought I would comment on this. 1st, it is very clear that when the boy gets hit in the movie, he is not hurt! Therefore, IT IS NOT REAL!!! In the movie "The Ring", when the little girl is killed and then thrown down the well to drown, it seems very real and horrifying. In Scary Movie 3, it is like the 3 Stooges hitting each other, very slapstick and non-threatening cartoon violence. 2ND, NO ONE SEEMS TO REALIZE THAT IT IS A SPOOF OF THE MOVIE "IDENTITY", which came out this past spring. That movie was a murder mystery slightly horror film, and twice someone in that movie died by being hit very realistically by a car at a high speed. ALSO, this same type of horrible death happened in "Final Destination 1 & 2". So Scary Movie 3 is spoofing all three of these movies. Those grumpy grouchy reviewers who gripe about this obviously didn't see these movies, so they have NO IDEA WHATSOEVER that the writer/director is making fun of these other horror movies. It would be nice if people go see a movie making fun of other movies, THAT THEY FIRST GO SEE THE MOVIES THAT ARE BEING MADE FUN OF!!! Then maybe they would appreciate the humor in the spoofing film!The one real complaint I had was that I thought this movie should have been rated an R rating. My God, parents, WHAT ARE YOU THINKING WHEN YOU TAKE LITTLE CHILDREN TO THESE MOVIES???? AND THEN AMERICA WONDERS WHERE ALL THE PSYCHOS COME FROM WHO SHOW UP DERANGED AND CRAZY ON THE JERRY SPRINGER SHOW!!! They had parents who were stupid and could care less about their children, who drag their kids to violent and vulgar and sexually perverse movies, that is where they come from. Review title: This Movie is like 20 Steps up from Scary Movie 2
Review_body: With such horror movies like, Scream and I know What You Did Last Summer. Keenan Ivory Wayans was able to spawn Scary Movie. Scary Movie was hilarious and basically made fun of the teen horror films like Scream. I remember watching it and laughing my head off. Scary Movie 2 was awful and terrible and not remotely funny whatsoever. It seem like the Scary Movie series was done. But not so. Now we get a new director named David Zucker (Airplane and Naked Gun series) and some of the same cast from the first minus Shawn and Marlon Wayans and added some funny spoof from Signs, The Ring and Matrix Reloaded and now we have a step up from Scary Movie 2.Anna Faris is back as Cindy Campbell and Regina Hall is back as Brenda Meeks. Let's face it without Anna and Regina, the Scary Movie series can just basically stop. They both are hilarious. A tape that kills you in seven days is swirling around that Cindy saw and now she is trying to warn everyone about it.The movie does some funny spoof of Signs (yeah, they stick it to Shaymalan again), The Ring, Matrix Reloaded, and 8 Mile . It is not as funny as The R rated Scary Movie but it has that Airplane comedy feel and it made me chuckle a lot and is 10 times better than the second installment.So if you want a good laugh at some crazy spoofs, watch Scary Movie 3.

The movies parodied include: Signs, the 6th Sense, 8 mile, the Ring, and in the alternate ending, the Incredible Hulk. The alternate endings available on the DVD, altho shot on a noticeably much lower budget, were much funnier than the original. Perhaps this is because I had actually seen the movies being parodied in the alternate endings, but I liked them better. The "6th Sense" ending, which focused on Cody, was pretty stupid, even if you have actually seen that movie. I didn't see Signs, and don't plan to, but my friend informed me that a running joke in the movie, "swing away", is based on that. I didn't think it was funny, and I thought it sucked that the pivitol points of the movie were based on that.

Review title: A Step-Down From Good Spoofs, A Step-Up From It's Prequel
Review_body: Scary Movie 3 tries to be original, but at times (which is most of the time) it isn't. The plot? Well it's not too hard to explain. In short: The Ring + Signs. It also tries to be bad while still being good (It tries to be "R" rated while being "PG-13"). Some scenes are sharp and funny, like the opening scene, but others are just way too far-out and/or gross, like the end. The ending is also dissapointing. But to the story overall, it's in a special area of films that fall between the good and the bad. It tries to be as good as spoof films like Austin Powers, or the first Scary Movie, but at least it's better then some spoofs like Not Another Teen Movie or Scary Movie (2 That is). Suprisingly, it has alot of cameos, mainly by African-American actors (Macy Grey's in it for a short short time, she only has one line (The film never supplies a reason why she has to be in the film)). But now bringing up the subject of the actors, the film takes a huge part at making Black jokes which can be funny for some actors (Regina Hall is hilarious once again in this film) but others, it just doesn't work. So, the fact of the matter is, don't waste your time in the theaters. Wait for if you want for DVD, but then, it's still not worth it. P.S. In the trailers a scene shows Eddie Griffen, Queen Latifah, and Anna Faris in a scene spoofing the original Matrix (Eddie: "I am Orpheous!"), but in the film, this scene, which seemed promising is no where to be found at all. Let's hope it'll be a deleated scene on the DVD. C+ -or- * * (Two Stars).

Review title: Most of the gags worked; a few didn't.
Review_body:
Pros:-several very well constructed gags-a dash or two of intelligent humor-immensely better than #2Cons:-slight overuse of slapstick-the occasional joke falls flat
Only in a film like this would you find a parody of a beer commercial... Perhaps it was an homage to the "Wazzup" segment in the first film.Segment really is the key word; this film is essentially like an episode of "Family Guy", in that each scene really serves as an elaborate setup for a series of gags, and not much concern is given to advancing the plot. This segmented feel works famously in a film which is clearly not meant in the least to be taken seriously, although some jokes, such as the Simon Cowell cameo, seemed forced. While a few gags seemed to come straight out of the Farrelly Brothers handbook of moviemaking, the film tries to stay original with its parodies (if such a thing is possible). Sheen and Faris clearly have a great time in their respective roles.A few running gags clearly marked this as a David Zucker film, particularly the frequent use of slapstick humor. While this seems unnecessarily repetitive at first, it becomes essentially a running gag as one character is repeatedly singled out for each hit. A lot of gags worked; some didn't. I suppose it's to be expected with a film like this. But the film wasn't overshadowed by the numerous woeful comedic leaps of its predecessor during which the audience was expected to be laughing. For the most part this time around, I actually was laughing. Hopefully the Wayans Brothers learned a thing or two from the sidelines.6.5/10

Review title: Possibly, correction, Definitely the worst movie I have ever seen.
Review_body: I realize that Zucker movies are supposed to be absurd, but al least the first Airplane' and Police Squad' had organized plots and story lines. Scary Movie 3' was a disjointed unfunny joke.  Over half the scenes in the movie left me confused and disappointed.  It was almost the first movie that I walked out of early (years ago I rented The House of Cats' and ejected the tape from the top-loader VCR after about 20 minutes).  Instead of playing it safe and leaving I punished myself by staying and waiting for the movie to get funny.  It never did.Maybe the movie theater didn't run the opening reel of the film, as the version I saw was ONLY 75 MINUTES LONG.  Even so I was worried when the rep from Dimension films that introduced the film said, `you are among the first people in Baltimore to see this film.  If you like it tell your friends, if you don't maybe come see it again and give it another chance.  Enjoy the film!'  Yeah right.  Who were they tying to fool?  I want to know what the actors in this film were thinking.  The producers must have either offered them a ton of money or only showed them their portions of the screenplay.  The unconnected individual scenes were sometimes amusing but many of the movie rip-offs were wasted.  There was so much potential, especially with the Matrix scenes, but the advance screening audience and I were left high and dry.  Sight gags can only go so far to carry a movie and the ones in Scary Movie 3 were few, fleeting and spread too far apart.The scenes did nothing to advance the plot of the movie.  You will quickly realize that when the first scene with Pamela Anderson and Jenny McCarthy both starts and ends with no explanation that the whole film is going to follow the same disjointed pattern.  Save your money.  Save your time (even though you would only be wasting 75 minutes).  Save your sanity.  Save Yourself.  Don't ever watch Scary Movie 3'.0 out of 100.
